sameAnalysis.part_name: 这些形容词都表示"完整的，全部的，整个的"之意。
sameAnalysis.word_list: entire, whole, complete, full, total, gross, all
means: entire ： 除了有whole的意思外，还强调既不能加一个也不减少一个的含义。
whole比entire更普通，强调每个组成部分都包括在内，无一漏掉或舍去。
complete ： 强调事物在内容、程度、或数量方面已完整，已达标准。
full ： 侧重指内容，含有能包括所有的充足内容的意味。
total与complete用法相近，但强调总量。
gross ： 侧重指未打折扣，未除去成本或皮重等与净重、净数相对。

word_mean: 边缘光滑的：指菌落平整、光滑，无隆起或缺凹

sentence.Network_en: If the Commission has its way, the entire deal will be scuppered.

sentence.Network_en: They feared that totalitarians might yet conquer the entire world.
sentence.Network_cn: 他们担心极权主义者会征服整个世界。

derivation.yuyuan_name: late Middle English (formerly also as intire): from Old French entier, based on Latin integer 'untouched, whole', from in- 'not' + tangere 'to touch'

entry.def: You use entire when you want to emphasize that you are referring to the whole of something, for example, the whole of a place, time, or population.

example.ex: He had spent his entire life in China as a doctor...
example.tran: 他一生都在中国当医生。

example.ex: There are only 60 swimming pools in the entire country...
example.tran: 全国总共只有60个游泳池。

means.word_mean: 1. constituting the full quantity or extent; complete;

sentences.sentence: "an entire town devastated by an earthquake"

means.word_mean: 2. constituting the undiminished entirety; lacking nothing essential especially not damaged;

sentences.sentence: "a local motion keepeth bodies integral"- Bacon
"was able to keep the collection entire during his lifetime"

means.word_mean: 3. (of leaves or petals) having a smooth edge; not broken up into teeth or lobes

Sentence.sentence: Last week I came across a couple of old school friends and we spend the entire journey in the bar.
And one medical program at the University of California, Irvine, gave their entire class iPads with which to download textbooks just last year.
But in the end he created a reality of his own, channeling the magic of computing into products that reshaped entire industries.
The butterflies are so numerous that they often cover the entire trees.
Disaster movies often portray catastrophes that destroy, or at least threaten to destroy earth's entire population.

Major supermarkets, in meeting consumer expectations, will often reject entire crops of perfectly edible fruit and vegetables at the farm because they do not meet exacting marketing standards for their physical characteristics, such as size and appearance.
